videos.title: 2024 GRiT Maximus full course and a crash!
videos.description:
I rode my ebike in the (Almost) Anything Goes category of the GRiT Gravel Adventure Ride on the 63-mile Maximus course at Snoqualmie Pass, WA.  There were four major climbs and the last was a beast.

Overall 211 people competed in this timed event, with 69 doing the Maximus, the longest course in the series.  The event had amazing support, including traffic control on the paved roads and an outstanding and well staffed and stocked aide station that we were routed past three times.

I did crash on downhill #3, but after a consult with the event medic I decided to keep going for another 24 miles and I think it helped the swelling on my knee go down.

Overall it was a great ride, very well organized and supported.

I rode my Biktrix Juggernaut FS Pro 3 with dual 52v batteries (17.5Ah main + 17Ah extender) and finished with about 16% remaining.

videos.title: Crash during the 2024 GRiT Gravel Adventure Ride
videos.description:
The GRiT Gravel Adventure ride is a 60+ mile timed ride event through the mountains above Snoqualmie Pass, WA.  Some of the terrain can be pretty treacherous as I encountered in this clip.

At the bottom of the hill I consulted with the event medic, and despite a golf ball sized hematoma on my knee he cleared me to continue, and over the next 24 miles it actually worked it self down so it wasn't as bad by the time I drove home.  I was still pretty stiff and sore, and I had to order a new rear rack because the crash snapped the one I had.

Overall it was a fun ride, despite this incident, and it was very well supported.  Look for the full video on this page.

videos.title: Are The Fastest Gravel Tyres Worth It?
videos.description:
We’ve been testing the Hutchinson Caracal Race TLR – a gravel tyre that prioritises speed and efficiency. But does that come at the cost of off-road grip and control? Our testing dives into how the tyres perform across different terrain, and how to decide whether tyres like this are a good match for your gravel bike.
 
Do you need to sacrifice off-road traction for on-road performance? And what does this mean for how we set up our bikes? The Caracal Race has us rethinking what gravel riding even is – and what we want from our tyres.
 
From dry hardpack to looser trails, we’ve put these tyres through a range of real-world conditions and come away with a few opinions – and even more questions.

videos.transcript:
Shopping for road bike tires is easy.
There are just three steps. Step one,
you go to bicycle rollingresistant.com.
You look up what the fastest tires are.
Step two, you Google, you chose a model,
and you look for a good price. Step
three, you click buy. That's it. Simple,
easy peasy. Now, sure, there are other
things like puncture resistance, grip,
weight, so on. But let's face it, these
days, most allrounder racing tires from
the big names are pretty similar, and
you can't really go too far wrong. But
shopping for gravel bike tires, not so
easy. Yeah, you can go online and look
up what the fastest gravel bike tires
are, but then you start thinking, hm,
that tire looks a lot like a big road
tire. Is it really a gravel tire? Won't
I need some tread for grip when you're
riding off road? Well, today I'm going
to tell you.
[Music]
These are Hutchinson's Caracal Race TLR
tires, and they cost £54.99
per tire. Now, if you go to bicycle
rollingresistance.com, you'll see that
these are currently listed as the fourth
fastest tire in the CX/ravel
category. And if you look a little bit
closer, you'll realize that the three
faster tires aren't really gravel tires
at all. They're just slicks. Now,
Hutchinson's Caracle Race is the most
efficient gravel tire with a tread of at
least 1 mm on the shoulders. But is it
any good, though? Is that actually
enough grip? And is it actually tough
enough to use as a gravel tire? Well,
I've been using this and its tougher and
much slower sibling, the Caracle TLR,
for a while now, and I've got some
conclusions. I also think they raise
some really interesting questions about
how we think about gravel riding and how
we should set up our bikes for it.
First of all, yes, these are really fast
gravel tires, and you can feel that
immediately, where most gravel tires
tend to feel pretty draggy on the road,
especially if you're coming off a road
bike with racy tires like Conti GP5000s,
for example. These, though, don't feel
far off a proper road tire on the road,
yet they're capable of floating over
broken tarmac, hard pack dirt roads, and
so on. And really that shouldn't be a
surprise as according to the lab data,
these are actually faster than 38 mm
Shawby Pro ones, which is a proper road
racing tire with a completely slick
tread. Of course, at around 470 g each,
these tires do add a decent chunk of
weight to a bike compared to 28s or the
30s that most of us run on road bikes
these days. And yes, that is going to
make you fractionally slower on the
climbs. However, we're all grown up
enough to know that that just comes with
the territory. If you want bigger tires
so that you can get more grip and lower
roll resistance off-road, then that
inevitably means more material and more
weight. That's just how it goes. There
is of course an argument to be had about
how much tire volume you actually need,
but that's a topic for another video.
Now, in terms of puncture resistance, I
think it's fair to say that these tires,
like most at the racy end of this
spectrum, aren't going to be performing
miracles. Now, I've not suffered any
punctures with either model so far, but
as a relatively lightweight rider, I'm
also a bit easier on my kit than many
riders, and I've been running inserts to
guard against pinch flats. Of course,
it's possible that I've simply been
lucky, too, but nevertheless, I think if
you treat them well, then they will hold
up okay.
All right, so far so good. These sound
like they're everything they're cracked
up to be, right? Well, in a sense, yeah,
if the conditions suit these tires, then
I think they're fantastic. Hutchinson
even recently announced a 45mimeter
version will be available from June this
year, which is great as these 40mm
versions are starting to feel relatively
narrow by modern gravel standards.
Inevitably though, there are some
trade-offs. Part of what makes these
tires so fast on the road is the slick
central section and minimalist tread on
the shoulders, but that can come back to
bite you off-road if the conditions get
tricky. When things get loose or worse,
wet and muddy, then these tires simply
do not bite into the trail, you will run
out of grip extremely quickly.
And this is where we come to the crux of
the issue with gravel tires. Is it fair
to criticize the Caracle Race for not
being good as something it's not
designed to do? Now, this is a race tire
designed for dry conditions rather than
an all rounder after all. So, you could
argue that it's not unexpected that it
trades grip for speed. That's simply
part of the calculation. The problem is
that gravel can mean so many different
things and what constitutes a gravel
ride can be even more varied. Now, where
I live in South Bristol, even piecing
together every farm track and byway that
I can find still leaves me with roots
totaling at least around 50% tarmac
roads and typically far more. Now, in
those scenarios, even if the trails are
fairly loose or rocky, then I don't want
slower, grippier tires that are going to
feel rubbish for the vast majority of my
rides just because they're perfect for
the toughest off-road sections. Now, on
the other hand, if you're gearing up for
Unbound Kansas, which is almost all
off-road, then it's unlikely that you're
going to be served by something that's
essentially an extra-lar road tire. Now,
for terrain like that, it's starting to
look like you might want a set of
crosscountry mountain bike tires,
assuming your bike can fit them, of
course. The reality is that there's no
one perfect gravel tire that can do
almost everything in the same way a
Conti GP5000 or Victoria Corsera Pro can
do on a road bike. All else being equal,
narrower gravel tires with less tread
tend to be faster on the tarmac because
they're lighter, bit more arrow, and you
simply don't need as much tire volume to
deal with bumps in the road. Off-road
though, bigger tires can be faster
because they're better able to absorb
imperfections in the trail. And if you
swap up to fast XC mountain bike tires
can be made with thinner casings so that
they have even lower rolling resistance.
And deciding which way to go really
depends on where you're going to be
riding. If you really care about
optimizing your bike setup, then you're
going to need to change your times every
time you ride a substantially different
route or more likely be prepared to
compromise on something. Now, in my
case, I actually think these tires offer
a great balance of the characteristics
for the kind of gravel riding that I do.
I've definitely had some sketchy moments
when using these on wet or loose trails,
but for the mostly dry days, the
trade-off feels well worth it. But what
do you think? Is rolling resistance the
be all and end all for gravel bike
tires, or is it better to go for
something that offers a better balance
of speed and grip? Or should we really
all be using XC mountain bike tires on
our gravel bikes all of the time? As
always, let me know your thoughts in the
comments below. And if you liked this
video, why not watch this one where we
reveal the real differences between a
$1,200 and $12,000 gravel bike.

videos.title: Scouting trip of the GRiT Fortis route - May 27th, 2024
videos.description:
I'm planning to ride the GRiT Adventure Gavel Ride at Snoqualmie Pass on July 20th, 2024 so I decided to scout the middle-distance route, called "Fortis" on Memorial Day, 2024.  I was blocked from completing it by snow covering the trail at 3500 feet and 3250 feet near Lost Lake.

I rode on a Biktrix Juggernaut FS Pro 3 with dual 52v 17Ah batteries.

videos.title: 2024 GRiT Maximus Scouting Ride
videos.description:
I rode the GRiT Maximus course on July 11th, 2024.  This route covers all the ground of the Fortis and Velox as well, so if you are planning to ride this will give you a good idea of what to expect regardless of which route you choose.  Most of the video is at 10x speed so you don't have to suffer through 5-hours of riding.

https://thegrit.bike/event-details-grit-2024/

I rode on a BikTrix Juggernaut FS Pro 3 mid-drive ebike with dual 52v 17Ah batteries.
